The History of Farming Before people started farming they went to the forest to look for plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were moving all the time to find food. In Europe farmers started growing crops like wheat and oats. In America the Native Americans grew maize, beans and squash. The history of farming is long and complex. ICE-FISHING If you drive north from Toronto for three hours you come to Lake Nipissing. In winter the lake becomes ice and thousands of Canadian fishermen travel there each weekend. They build little houses of wood on the ice and paint them in bright colours. Then they sit inside to catch the fish that swim under the ice. This is ice-fishing.  The fishermen sit in their little houses and wait for a bite. They have to be very quiet so they don't scare the fish away. They use special rods with a hook on the end and bait on the hook. When the fish bites, the fisherman pulls the rod and the fish comes up through the hole in the ice. Then he pulls the fish out and puts it in his bucket.  If you go ice-fishing, be sure to dress warmly. You need a warm coat, a hat, gloves, and boots that are good for walking on the ice. You also need a special bag to sit on. It is also a chance to catch fish for dinner. Some people even eat the fish they catch right on the ice!  If you try ice-fishing, be sure to be careful. 'I am quite well' I always answered. Why did I say that? Why did I not ask for his help? Perhaps because in one sense it was true. I was not in pain. 'It cannot be the mysterious illness from the village' I thought. 'My illness is now three weeks old. It is my own personal hell, my own private purgatory.'

"But even as I thought these words, I knew that they were not true. I was in pain. I was in torment. I was in the grip of something that I could not control. 'I am quite well' I said, and yet I was not. I was not well at all. I was sick, sick to the very core of my being. And yet I said those words, and I believed them. I believed them because I had to. I had to believe them in order to survive.

"And so I said them, and I lied, and I deceived, and I cheated. And I knew that I was not alone in this. I knew that everyone else was doing the same. Everyone else was pretending to be well, when they were not. Everyone else was pretending to be happy, when they were not. Everyone else was pretending to be content, when they were not. And I knew that I was not the only one who was pretending. I knew that I was not the only one who was hiding behind a mask of false cheerfulness.

"And so I said those words, and I lied, and I deceived, and I cheated. And I knew that I was not alone in this. And I knew that I was not the only one who was suffering.

Otters are very good in the water and can swim at more than 10 kilometres an hour. They have thick brown hair and this keeps them warm in the water. They also have sharp claws and a long tail that they use to swim.
Otters are very good at hunting. They eat fish, crabs, and other small animals. They can hold their breath underwater for a long time. They also have a special way of swimming called a slither. This means they can slide through the water very fast.
Otters are very friendly animals and like to play with other animals. They also like to rest in the sun and bask in the warmth.
Otters are very important to the environment. They help keep the rivers and lakes healthy by eating fish that might eat too many plants. They also help keep the rivers and lakes clean by eating dead fish and other things that might pollute the water.
Otters are very interesting animals and are fun to watch. They are also very important to the environment.

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop age 14 Last summer I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day we took a trip to a park not far from our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens but we were only interested in the elephant show. We went straight to a large square with seats on three sides. In the middle was a large pond with a large wooden stage. We waited for about half an hour for the show to start. When it did, the elephants came out one by one and walked around the stage. They were so tall and big, with wrinkled skin and big ears. The first elephant did tricks, like spinning around and picking up things with its trunk. Then, it was time for the elephant to paint. It held a brush in its trunk and painted a beautiful picture of a tree. The audience gasped in amazement. Next, the elephant played soccer with a ball on its trunk. It was very funny. Finally, the elephant did a magic trick. It made things disappear and reappear on the stage. The show ended and we left the park, all of us very happy. I enjoyed the show very much and I will never forget the elephants. I hope to see them again someday.

THE ICEHOTEL For many years the Arctic was a popular destination in the summer season to see the land of the midnight sun but in winter the few inhabitants had the snow and ice to themselves. By the end of the 1980s it was decided that the dark and cold winter should be seen as an advantage. The Icehotel in Jukkasjarvi Sweden was born. The first guests arrived in 1990 and since then the hotel has been rebuilt every winter using ice and snow from the Torne River. The Icehotel is a unique and magical place that has to be experienced to be believed. Each winter the hotel is rebuilt using around 20000 tons of ice and 100000 pieces of snow. The rooms are designed and built by a team of skilled ice sculptors from around the world. They use a variety of techniques to shape and carve the ice into beautiful and intricate designs. The hotel has 55 rooms and suites each one different and unique. Some are designed to look like ice palaces while others resemble ice igloos. The guests can enjoy a range of activities such as dog sledding snowmobiling and even flying over the Arctic landscape in a hot air balloon. The Icehotel also offers a range of dining options from traditional Swedish cuisine to gourmet meals. The Icehotel is a truly unique and unforgettable experience that is not to be missed.

Climbing to the top of Britain Each year thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland and because of its northerly location the climate can be bitterly cold. Climber Keith Hewitt describes his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February my first big winter climb. Our route was up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. I was with a small group of experienced climbers all with our own reasons for tackling the mountain that day. I was there to test myself physically mentally and spiritually. We set off at midnight and climbed through the night to reach the summit at dawn. The climb was difficult and exposed with steep rock and ice climbing sections. But the real challenge was the cold the wind and snow. We were fully clothed in layers and with gloves hats and goggles to protect us from the elements. The coldest part of the climb was at the top where the wind whipped around the summit. We huddled together to take photos and I remember thinking I can do this but what on earth am I doing here? The climb down was just as challenging with the added pressure of darkness and fatigue. We made it back to base camp at 4pm exhausted and exhilarated. I had faced my fears and pushed myself beyond my limits. And as I looked up at Ben Nevis I knew I would be back again someday. Climbing to the top of Britain's highest peak is an experience that stays with you for a long time. The sense of accomplishment the breathtaking views and the camaraderie with fellow climbers make it a challenge that many people want to repeat. Grass Grass is probably the most successful living plant in the world. There are over 9000 different types of grasses and they are found in every region on the earth. They are the single flowering plants that can exist in the freezing environment of the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands support a wide range of animal life from tiny insects and birds to huge animals like cows and lions. Grasses have been cultivated for thousands of years and are a staple crop in many parts of the world. In this essay we will explore the biology of grass, its evolution, the different types of grasses, their uses, and their importance in the ecosystem. Grass is a type of herbaceous plant that belongs to the family Poaceae. It is characterized by narrow leaves that are arranged in a parallel pattern along the stem, and a distinctive hollow stem that is usually green in color. The flowers of grass are small and inconspicuous, typically produced in a spike or panicle. The most common type of grass is the warm-season grasses such as Bermuda grass, zoysia grass, and buffalo grass. These types of grasses are found in tropical and subtropical regions of the world and are used for lawns, golf courses, and other landscaping purposes. The cool-season grasses such as Kentucky bluegrass, perennial ryegrass, and tall fescue are found in temperate regions and are used for lawns, pastures, and hay fields. Grasses have evolved over millions of years, with the earliest known grasses dating back to the Cretaceous period, around 100 million years ago. Maria Mutola In 1988 Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl in an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. 'We won' she said. 'At first no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' The story appeared in a local newspaper and Jose Craveirinha who had encouraged other African athletes learnt about Maria. He contacted her and invited her to join the national team. She was 15. In 1990 she won her first international medal at the World Junior Championships in Sudbury, Canada. In 1993 she won the 800m and 1500m double at the World Championships in Stuttgart, Germany. In 1996 she won the Olympic silver medal in the 800m in Atlanta. She retired from competitive running in 2006. Maria Mutola, born 1972, Mozambique.

At just 15 years old, Mutola began her international career and went on to win numerous medals, including the 800m and 1500m double at the World Championships in Stuttgart, Germany in 1993. She also won the Olympic silver medal in the 800m in Atlanta in 1996. Mutola retired from competitive running in 2006, leaving behind a legacy as a trailblazer for women in sports in Africa and beyond.

THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains run almost the length of North America. They start in the North-west but lie only a few hundred miles from the centre in more southern areas. Detective-Inspector Cornish and Chief-Inspector Craddock were discussing the murder at the local police station. 'Mrs Bantry said that Marina Gregg had a "frozen look"' said Cornish. 'Did she see someone on the stairs? There were two people from America - Ardwyck Fenn and Lola Brewster a film star. The murderer must have been one of them.'

'It's possible,' said Craddock. 'But we need more evidence. The frozen look could have been due to shock or fright rather than seeing someone on the stairs. And we know that Mrs Bantry is not the most reliable of witnesses.'

'Quite,' agreed Cornish. 'But what about the letter found in the library? It was addressed to "My dearest darling". Could it have been from the murderer?'

'It's possible,' said Craddock again. 'But we need to be careful. We don't want to jump to conclusions. We need to follow up on all the leads and see where they take us.'

'Agreed,' said Cornish. 'I'll interview the Bantrys again and see if they remember anything else. And I'll also speak to the other guests. Maybe someone saw something.'

'Good luck with that,' said Craddock. 'And keep an open mind. The killer could be anyone.'

In this conversation, Detective-Inspector Cornish and Chief-Inspector Craddock are discussing the murder at the local police station. They are considering the evidence they have gathered so far, including Mrs Bantry's description of the victim's "frozen look" and the letter found in the library

Winter Driving Winter is dangerous because it's so difficult to know what is going to happen and accidents take place so easily. Fog can be waiting to meet you over the top of a hill. Ice might be hiding beneath the melting snow waiting to send you off the road. And, of course, it's dark early. So what can you do to stay safe on the road during the winter?

1.	Slow down. The most important rule of winter driving is to slow down. The faster you are going, the longer it will take you to stop if you encounter ice, snow, or other hazards on the road. It's also more difficult to control your vehicle if you are going too fast.

2.	Know your vehicle. Make sure you know how your vehicle handles in snowy and icy conditions. If you have a four-wheel drive or all-wheel drive vehicle, it will handle better in winter conditions. However, if you have a two-wheel drive vehicle, it may be more difficult to handle in the snow.

3.	Check your tires. Make sure your tires are properly inflated and have good tread. If your tires are worn or under-inflated, they may not provide enough traction on icy or snowy roads.

4.	Use winter tires. Winter tires are specifically designed to handle in snowy and icy conditions. They have a special tread pattern that provides better traction on slippery roads. If you live in an area that gets a lot of snow, consider investing in a set of winter tires.

5.	Keep a safe distance.

LITTLE CAT LITTLE CAT WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van she had a bigger adventure than she expected. She was discovered by the driver after he had completed a trip of over 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day. The driver of the furniture van was getting ready to pull into the parking lot of his home when he heard a faint meowing sound coming from outside the back of his van. He opened the doors to find a tiny cat hiding in a pile of boxes. The cat, who was later named Bo, was dirty and tired but otherwise unharmed. The driver had no idea where the cat had come from or how it had ended up in his van. Bo had been on quite the adventure. She had managed to squeeze herself into a small gap between the van and a nearby building before the driver had closed the doors. She must have fallen asleep while hiding there, and when the driver had started driving, she had been carried along for the ride. Bo was a little scared at first, but she was also curious and excited to see where she was going. She had never been in a van before, and she loved the feeling of moving and the new sights and smells. Bo stayed with the driver for a few days before he found a home for her with a family who loved cats. She was happy and content in her new home, but she never forgot her wild adventure on the furniture van. She would often tell her new family about the places she had been and the things she had seen on her journey. She was a little cat with a big spirit, and she had experienced a bigger adventure than she ever could

THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria in Egypt in 370 A.D. For many centuries she was the only woman scientist to have a place in the history books. Hypatia's father was director of Alexandria University and he made sure his daughter had the best education available. This was unusual as most women then had few opportunities to study. Hypatia became proficient in mathematics, astronomy, and philosophy. She was so good that she became famous throughout the Mediterranean world. She taught at the university and was known for her clarity of thought and her ability to explain complex ideas in simple terms. Hypatia was also an accomplished mathematician and astronomer. She wrote commentaries on the works of the Greek mathematician and astronomer Ptolemy. Ptolemy had written a major work on astronomy called the Almagest. Hypatia's commentaries were highly regarded and helped to establish her reputation as a leading scientist. In addition to her scientific work, Hypatia was also a philosopher. She was particularly interested in the philosophy of Plato and Aristotle. She was known for her eloquence and her ability to use logic to defend her views. Hypatia was also a strong advocate for the rights of women. She believed that women should have equal opportunities with men in education and in public life. She was a pioneer in a time when women had few opportunities for advancement. Hypatia's life was cut tragically short. In 415 A.D. a group of Christian extremists attacked her and dragged her through the streets of Alexandria. She was brutally murdered. Norwich Norwich the capital of the part of Britain known as East Anglia has existed as a place to live for more than two thousand years. It began as a small village beside the River Wensum. At the time of the Norman invasion in 1066 it had grown to become one of the largest towns in England. In the Middle Ages it was a major commercial center and a center for the wool and textile industry.
Norwich Cathedral is one of the most famous landmarks in Norwich. It was built in the 11th century and is one of the finest examples of Norman architecture in Europe. The Cathedral is home to the shrine of St. John Plessington and St. John Fisher, two Catholic martyrs who were executed in the 16th century.
The Castle Museum is another popular attraction in Norwich. It features exhibits on the history of Norwich and the surrounding area. The museum also hosts temporary exhibitions and events throughout the year.

Sharks ‚Ä®Sharks are some of the most frightening creatures in our oceans. They are well prepared for feeding under water because they can see very well and they can also feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. These make sharks very dangerous for smaller sea creatures that become their food. Sharks have been around for over 400 million years and they have survived many changes in the Earth's climate. Because of their long history, sharks have developed very efficient ways of finding food and avoiding predators. Sharks are also very good at taking care of their young. They are born alive and can swim and hunt on their own within a few weeks of being born. 

Sharks are a diverse group of fish, with over 500 species, ranging in size from the small dwarf lanternshark, which is only 20 cm (8 in) long, to the whale shark, which can grow up to 18 meters (59 ft) in length. Sharks are found in all the world's oceans, from the shallowest coastal waters to the deepest parts of the ocean.

Some species of sharks are known for their distinctive features, such as the hammerhead, which has a flattened, hammer-shaped head, and the great white shark, which has a distinctive white underside. Other species are known for their aggressive behavior, such as the tiger shark, which is known to attack a wide variety of prey, including other sharks.

Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland and winter temperatures there can reach -40¬∞ C. But 6000 holidaymakers still go there annually to visit what is probably Europe's most unusual accommodation. In this hotel you eat drink and sleep in rooms made of ice. If you want you can even get married in one.
The Ice Hotel is built every year from the end of November to the end of April. The structure is made of 2000 tons of ice and snow and contains some 5000 cubic meters of ice. The rooms and the ice bar are all designed and built by a team of 40 artists and ice sculptors from Sweden and around the world.
The beds are made of ice too and are so cold that you are given a special ice bed mattress to keep warm. The ice walls are just 30 cm thick and the temperature inside the hotel is around -5¬∞ C. But don't worry, the hotel provides warm clothing and sleeping bags to keep you cozy.
The hotel also features an ice chapel where you can get married in a truly unique setting. The weddings are conducted by a local priest and are legally recognized in Sweden.
The Ice Hotel is a popular destination for honeymooners and many couples have chosen this unusual venue for their special day.
The Ice Hotel is not the only ice hotel in the world. There are others in Finland, Canada and the United States, but the one in Jukkasjarvi is the original and the largest.
Sweden is a country of great natural beauty and the Ice Hotel is just one of the many unique experiences that can be found there.
You can find more information about the Ice Hotel

SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time like disease an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about his personal life including his love life and his job as an administrator at the Navy Office. Pepys was born in 1633 in Salisbury England. He studied at Cambridge University and later became a member of Parliament. In 1660 he was appointed as the Secretary to the Admiralty by King Charles II. Pepys kept his diary for 10 years from 1660 to 1670. He wrote in it every day except Sundays and often included details of his social life and his relationships with his friends and family. Pepys diary is considered a valuable historical document because it provides a unique perspective on life in 17th century England. It is also a fascinating insight into the personal life of a man who was an important figure in the political and social life of his time. Pepys died in 1703 at the age of 70 but his diary continues to be read and studied by historians and scholars today. It is considered one of the most important sources of information about the Restoration period in English history.

The History of Shoes In the past importance was not given to shoes being comfortable or fashionable. These early foot coverings were probably animal skins which people tied round their ankles during cold weather. We still use leather today but other materials such as silk plastic or cotton are also popular depending on what is in fashion. Shoes have been around for thousands of years with some of the earliest known designs dating back to ancient civilizations in Egypt Mesopotamia and Greece. In these cultures shoes were seen as more than just a practical item but also as a status symbol and a reflection of one's wealth and social standing. In ancient Rome sandals were popular and were often decorated with intricate designs and adornments such as gold and silver. During the Middle Ages in Europe shoes were mainly made of leather and were often highly decorated with elaborate designs and ornamentation. In the 18th and 19th centuries the Industrial Revolution led to the mass production of shoes which made them more accessible and affordable for the general population. This also led to the development of new materials such as rubber and plastic which were used in the production of shoes. In the 20th century the rise of fashion and celebrity culture led to the popularity of designer shoes and the emergence of new trends such as sneakers and athletic shoes. Today shoes come in a wide range of styles and materials and are an important part of fashion and culture. The history of shoes is a fascinating and diverse one reflecting the changing social and cultural values of different civilizations and time periods. From simple animal skins to high fashion designer shoes the evolution of footwear has had a profound

The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway travelled by train from Darwin in the north of Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses the Australian continent from the warm northern coast through seemingly endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the ‚Äòfamous Ghan‚Äô which is perhaps unfortunate since it is known above all for being late. Mark Ottaway travelled by train from Darwin in the north of Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses the Australian continent from the warm northern coast through seemingly endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the ‚Äòfamous Ghan‚Äô which is perhaps unfortunate since it is known above all for being late. The train journey is 1,467 miles (2,360 km) long and takes 54 hours. The train travels through the heart of Australia, passing through deserts, scrublands, and the MacDonnell Ranges. It also passes through the Finke Gorge National Park and the Devils Marbles. The Ghan train is named after the Afghan cameleers who helped to build the original railway line in the early 1900s. The train has three classes of service: Standard, Gold, and Platinum. The Standard Class has comfortable seats and a dining car, while the Gold Class has larger seats and a more extensive dining menu. The Platinum Class has the largest seats and a dedicated dining car. The Ghan train travels through some of the most remote areas of Australia, and it is not uncommon for the train to be delayed due to maintenance or weather conditions. Despite this, the Ghan train is a popular tourist attraction and an icon of Australian rail travel. Mark Ott

Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863 but he did not like farming. When he was fifteen he began work as a mechanic and in 1893 he built his first car. After he had driven it 1500 kilometres he sold it and built two bigger cars. In 1903 he founded the Ford Motor Company and his first car was the Model T. Henry Ford is famous for making cars affordable for ordinary people. He introduced new ways of working, such as the assembly line, which made cars faster and cheaper to build. Henry Ford also believed in paying his workers a fair wage so that they could afford to buy the cars they were making. Henry Ford was a very successful businessman and he changed the way cars were made and sold. He died in 1947 but his company is still one of the biggest car companies in the world.

No Title A month ago I had no idea that on a Saturday afternoon in November I'd be hanging 30 metres above the ground and enjoying it. Now I looked down at the river far below me and realised why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I had arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. We were both feeling a bit apprehensive about the climb, but our guide Mark quickly put us at ease. We were given a thorough briefing about the safety procedures, the equipment we would be using and the climbing techniques we would be learning. Mark was a great teacher and he had a way of making us feel confident and excited about the climb. On Saturday morning we set off early, eager to get started. The drive to the climbing spot took us through some beautiful countryside and we chatted excitedly about the adventure ahead. Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon I left my handbag on the bus. In it were my cheque book address book and my purse which contained about ¬£50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realised what I had done it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old I was a long way from home and I was quite worried. I called the bus company but they couldn't help me. I was very upset and I didn't know what to do.

I'm writing to ask if you can help me get my handbag back. I would be very grateful if you could put the word out in your paper and see if anyone has found it. I live in Newport and I'm sure someone must have seen it on the bus.

I'm also worried about the contents of the bag. My cheque book and address book contain personal information and I would be very upset if they fell into the wrong hands.

I'm sure you will understand how worried I am and I hope you can help me.

Yours sincerely
Mrs A. Smith.

San Francisco San Francisco lies on the coast of northern California. The earliest Europeans to discover the area were led by a Spanish explorer whose name was Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Surprisingly although San Francisco Bay is a wonderful natural harbour it was discovered by land rather than by sea. The Portola expedition camped near the mouth of the San Francisco River and named the area Yerba Buena or Good Herb. The area was then settled by Mexican in 1821 after Mexico gained independence from Spain. San Francisco became an important commercial center in the mid-1800s when the California Gold Rush brought a flood of people seeking to make their fortune in the gold fields. The town grew rapidly and in 1849 it was incorporated as a city. San Francisco has a mild climate and a beautiful setting with hills and the Pacific Ocean to the west and the San Francisco Bay to the east. The city is also known for its cultural diversity and its many museums and art galleries. The Golden Gate Bridge is one of the most famous landmarks in San Francisco and connects the city to Marin County. The city has also hosted many important events in American history including the 1906 earthquake and the start of the United Nations Charter in 1945. The city is also known for its unique architecture and the cable cars that run through the city. San Francisco is a popular tourist destination and is known for its vibrant nightlife and cultural attractions.
San Francisco is a major cultural and commercial center in California and is known for its unique blend of art and culture. The city has a rich history and has been home to many important events in American history

Hi - I'm Justin Rowlatt and I'm the BBC's 'Ethical Man'. So what does living ethically mean? Giving up the car recycling wine bottles not using plastic bags? I spent a year trying to find out. I want to be clear about one thing right from the start - it wasn't my idea to become the BBC's ethical man. It was a job offer, and at first I was a bit hesitant. I mean, who is this 'ethical man' character? And what exactly does he do? But the more I thought about it, the more I realized that this could be a really interesting experiment. I'm not a hippy, I'm not a tree-hugger, I'm just a regular guy who wants to make a difference. And so, I set out on a year-long journey to explore what it means to live an ethical life. I started by looking at the little things, the everyday choices that we all make without really thinking about them. Like using plastic bags, or buying products that are made with exploited labor. And I was surprised by how hard it is to avoid these things. It's not just a matter of making different choices, it's also about understanding the systems and structures that make it so hard to live ethically in the first place. For example, did you know that most supermarkets use plastic packaging that can't be recycled? Or that many of the clothes we buy are made in sweatshops where workers are paid poverty wages? It's not just about individual choices, it's about taking on the big corporations and governments that shape our world. And so, I started to look at bigger issues, like climate change and economic

MONEY What is money? The pound the dollar or the franc are actually just like a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can exchange money for something else. A five pound note may buy a book a huge bag of sweets or a couple of cinema tickets. But how can something that is only a piece of paper or a tiny chip of metal be worth anything? The answer is trust. Money is a way of trading goods and services but it is also a social construct a way of agreeing on what something is worth. The value of money is not set in stone it changes over time and it can vary from place to place. For example the dollar was once worth a lot more than it is now. And in some countries the currency is not even called dollars or pounds but instead is called something like the riyal or the rand. So what is money? It is a way of trading goods and services but it is also a way of agreeing on value. It is a social construct that can change over time and vary from place to place. It is a way of trusting that something will be worth something else in the future. It is a bit like a promise that you can rely on. And that is why money is so important to us. It is the way we trade with each other and it is the way we plan for the future. Without money we would not be able to buy the things we need or want. We would not be able to save for a rainy day or to invest in something that might make us money in the future. Money gives us the freedom to choose how we want to live our lives and to make the most of the opportunities that come our way. So the next time

Watering the Desert ‚Ä®It can rain at any time between November and March in Marrakesh Morocco. It doesn‚Äôt happen frequently and when it does the city‚Äôs water pipes can‚Äôt manage the sudden floods which turn the streets into rivers. But as many winters have remained dry in recent times when the rain does come it is welcomed by the local people.
Winter in Marrakesh is a time of hope for the city‚Äôs water supply. It is a time when the water table can be replenished and the parched earth can be revitalized. The rains are a reminder that life can be sustained in this desert city and that the land can still produce abundance despite the harsh conditions.
The rains also bring relief from the heat which can be intense in the winter months. The cooler temperatures and the possibility of rain create a sense of hope and optimism among the locals.

Charles Darwin (1809-1882) developed a revolutionary theory of evolution that transformed the way we understand the world and we see ourselves. In On the Origin of Species published in 1859 Darwin described the process of natural selection. The 'fittest' animals or plants - those with the characteristics best suited to their environment - are more likely to survive and reproduce. This means that over time species can change in response to their environment.

The theory of evolution by natural selection has had a profound impact on our understanding of biology and the natural world. It has also influenced fields such as anthropology, psychology, and sociology.

In this article we will explore the key elements of Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection and its implications for our understanding of the world and our place in it.

Key Elements of Darwin's Theory of Evolution by Natural Selection

1. Variation: Darwin recognized that species exhibit variation in their characteristics. This variation can arise from genetic differences or environmental factors.

2. Adaptation: Darwin observed that some species are better adapted to their environment than others. He argued that the 'fittest' individuals are more likely to survive and reproduce.

3. Heredity: Darwin recognized that the characteristics of an individual are determined by its genetic makeup. He believed that offspring inherit their parents' characteristics.

4. Natural Selection: Darwin proposed that the 'fittest' individuals in a population are more likely to survive and reproduce. This process leads to the evolution of the population over time.

5. Speciation: Darwin recognized that species can change over time. He proposed that new species can arise through geographic isolation or other mechanisms.

It‚Äôs true - we‚Äôre all getting too big for our boots Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy when he left school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris though still only fourteen was already almost two metres tall. And he's not alone. The average height of adults in the UK has increased by 10cms (four inches) in the past hundred years. So what's behind this growth spurt? Is it just better nutrition, or is there something else going on?

Well, the answer is a bit of both. But there's also something else - something that might just be the most surprising factor of all. It's called the 'Flynn effect'. You might not know it by name, but you'll definitely have heard of its most famous proponent - Michael Flynn, the American academic who first identified it back in 1987.

The Flynn effect is the phenomenon whereby every generation of children grows up to be taller than the last. And it's not just a matter of a bit of extra height here and there. The difference in height between a child born today and one born a hundred years ago is the equivalent of around three-and-a-half inches. That's a lot of growth.

So why is this happening? Well, Flynn himself suggested that it was down to better nutrition and healthcare. As societies have got richer, we've been able to provide our kids with more and better food, and our medical care has improved. That means they're growing up stronger and healthier, and

In 1998 the world-class Moroccan athlete Hicham El Guerrouj broke the 1500-metres world record with a time of three minutes twenty-six seconds. Nearly fifteen years later nobody has beaten that time. Have we got to the human speed limit? Dr Frances Ashcroft Professor of Physiology at Oxford University explains the limits of the human body during a race.

Dr. Ashcroft: "When you're running, the body has to deliver oxygen to the muscles to keep them working. The heart pumps blood to the muscles and the lungs take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide. The body has a limit to how much oxygen it can deliver to the muscles and how fast it can do it. This is called the VO2max."

Reporter: "So what is the current world record for the 1500-metres?"

Dr. Ashcroft: "The current world record is three minutes twenty-six seconds, set by Hicham El Guerrouj in 1998. That's an incredibly fast time, but it's also an incredibly high level of physical fitness. To break that record, you would need to have a VO2max of around 90-95 milliliters per kilogram per minute. Most elite athletes have a VO2max of around 70-80 milliliters per kilogram per minute, so there is still room for improvement."

At ten Jake and his wife Carla lay in the dark on the sofa waiting for the news. He had the remote in his hand, ready to flip to the local station if he heard anything about the trial, but there was nothing. He went to bed angry and frustrated, feeling as though he'd been cheated out of the news he'd been waiting for all day.

We are literally drowning in news. Have you ever tried reading the whole newspaper including the financial and sports pages? Or have you followed every piece of news on the front page of a news website? It's practically impossible. Reuters alone puts out 3.5 million news stories a year. And that's just one source.

With so much noise, it's hard to know what to pay attention to. It's easy to get sucked into the vortex of news and lose perspective. Even if you try to limit your intake, there's always something more to read, more to watch, more to listen to.

It's time to take back control of your news intake. Here are some strategies to help you stay informed without drowning in the noise:

1. Set boundaries: Decide how much time you want to spend on news each day and stick to it. Whether it's 30 minutes in the morning or an hour before bed, make it a non-negotiable part of your routine.
2. Prioritize sources: Choose the sources you trust the most and focus on them. Whether it's The New York Times, The Guardian, or NPR, make sure you're getting your news from reputable outlets.
3. Use filters: Use news aggregators like Apple News or Google News to filter out the noise and bring you the most important stories. You can also use social media platforms like Twitter or LinkedIn to curate your own feed and avoid the noise.

Trying to get published? If you are wondering where to send your story our expert Margaret Stubbs is here with the advice you need. Readers of this magazine often write in saying 'I have written this story / book. Where can I send it?'. We are always delighted to hear from would-be writers and we do our best to help you find the right place to send your work.

Firstly, let's consider the type of publication you are interested in. Are you looking for a traditional print magazine, or are you interested in online publications? Are you open to submitting to literary magazines, or do you prefer more commercial publications? Once you have a clear idea of what you are looking for, you can start researching the best places to submit your work.

There are many excellent literary magazines out there that are always looking for new and talented writers. Some of the most well-known include Granta, The Paris Review, and The New Yorker. These publications are highly competitive, but if you have a strong story to tell, they may be worth submitting to.

Another option is to look for smaller, independent publications that may be more open to new writers. These publications often have a more personal feel and may be more willing to take a chance on an unknown author. Some examples of these types of publications include The Lifted Brow, The Tusk, and The Rumpus.

Of course, there are also online publications that are always looking for new content. These can be a great way to get your work out there and gain exposure, even if you haven't had any previous publishing experience

In the weeks before the end of the tax year everyone in the firm was especially busy. With no wife to go home to Mitch worked later than anyone else. Besides he had extra work to do. One night at three in the morning he unlocked Avery's office on the fourth floor with one of the keys Abby had given him. Mitch had been working late every night for weeks, and his colleagues had started to notice. They'd catch him sneaking into the office after hours, or see him working on his laptop during meetings. Some of them had even begun to speculate about his personal life, whispering behind his back about how he must be "working on something big" to be putting in so many extra hours.

But Mitch wasn't working on anything big. He was just trying to keep up with the never-ending stream of work that seemed to come in at the worst possible times. Before then I had done bits of reviewing - novels for other newspapers films for a magazine and anything I was asked to do for the radio. But it was the job at The Front Page that really made me a critic. It was my first real taste of writing about film for a living and it was a great experience. Over the last ten years I have seen more films than I can count. I have always tried to be honest in my reviews and to give my readers a fair and balanced view of each film. I have never been afraid to give a bad review if that is what I truly believe. But I have also always tried to be fair and to give credit where it is due. I have seen some truly amazing films over the last ten years and I have been lucky enough to be able to share my thoughts on them with my readers. I have also seen some truly terrible films and I have been happy to tell my readers why they should avoid them. It has been a privilege to be able to write about film for The Front Page over the last ten years. I look forward to many more years of doing what I love.

Careers Advice You're not happy in your job at the moment but you don't know how to change? Kitty Doherty gives some good advice. The answer for more and more people who want to change their job is to turn to a careers adviser. You will be asked to write a brief history of yourself and then sit through a number of tests known as 'psychometrics'.
These are designed to help the adviser understand your personality and what you want from a job. The adviser will then use this information to suggest potential career paths that might be suitable for you.
It's important to remember that changing your job can be a long process, so don't expect to find a new job overnight. It can take months or even years to find the right job for you, so be patient and don't give up hope.
One of the best things you can do is to start networking, whether it's through LinkedIn or other means. This will help you make connections in your desired industry and learn more about what it's like to work in that field.
If you're not sure what you want to do, don't worry. Many people struggle with this and it's okay to take your time to figure things out. You can try taking a career assessment test or talking to a careers adviser to help you identify potential career paths.
Remember, changing your job can be a big decision, so take your time and don't rush into anything until you're sure it's right for you.

Studio Audiences What's it like to be in the audience when a television programme is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical difficultiesstudio audiences are just another common feature of television lifeand yet to many of us they remain a mystery. Watching them getting excited on game shows for example we sit back and ask ourselves - just who are these people? What do they do all day? And how on earth do they manage to stay so cheerful? The answers, it turns out, are surprisingly fascinating. In the first of a series of articles about television studio audiences, Cosmo Landesman set out to find out more. Audience members are often asked to attend a show a few times a week, and in some cases, they are required to attend every day. The pay varies depending on the show, but it's usually around ¬£20 to ¬£30 per day, plus expenses. They are expected to be on time, well-groomed, and prepared to follow any instructions given by the producers. The audience is usually made up of a mix of people from different walks of life, all chosen for their ability to react to what's happening on screen in an authentic and engaging way. They are usually seated in the front row of the studio, with the rest of the audience following their lead. Being in the audience for a television show can be a fun and exciting experience, but it can also be challenging. The audience members must remain completely silent during filming, and they are not allowed to talk to each other or make any noise. It‚Äôs true - we‚Äôre all getting too big for our boots Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy when he left school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris though still only fourteen was already almost two metres tall. And when he turned fifteen he grew another ten centimetres. By the time he was sixteen he was six feet three inches tall - and growing. And that was just the beginning. By the time he was twenty he was over seven feet tall. And as he approached his thirtieth birthday he was a staggering eight feet three inches tall - and still growing. It's a bit of a problem really. He can't fit into most cars - or most houses. He has to duck to avoid hitting his head on the low-hanging branches of trees. And he's had to give up his dream of joining the navy - because they don't have any ships big enough to accommodate him. So Chris has had to find a new career path - and he's currently considering a job as a circus performer. Because who wouldn't want to see the world's tallest man on a tightrope?

In April 1919 the British rulers in India decided to put down protests in the city of Amritsar. As people gathered in the public garden during the festival of Vaisakhi a British general ordered his soldiers to block the exits and shoot into the crowd. As well as thousands of injuries there were hundreds of deaths. The Amritsar Massacre as it became known was a turning point in the struggle for Indian independence.

This event is significant because:
A) It was the start of the non-cooperation movement led by Mahatma Gandhi.
B) It was a turning point in the struggle for Indian independence.
C) It was a response to the Rowlatt Act.
D) It was a result of the partition of India.

The answer is (B) The Amritsar Massacre was a turning point in the struggle for Indian independence. The massacre was a brutal and unnecessary act of violence that shocked the Indian people and galvanized the movement for independence. It marked a shift in the Indian nationalist movement, with many leaders and the public calling for more radical and direct action against British rule. The Amritsar Massacre is considered a turning point in the struggle for Indian independence because it raised awareness of the British government's brutal tactics and galvanized the movement for independence.

The other options are not accurate:

A) The non-cooperation movement led by Mahatma Gandhi started in 1920, a year after the Amritsar Massacre.

What would happen to our planet if humans were to suddenly disappear? This is the basic hypothesis behind Alan Weisman's book The World Without Us. Weisman examines how long it would take for humankind's mark on Earth to disappear. In one chapter there is an analysis of how New York would survive if there were no humans to take care of it.

The world would begin to return to its natural state.

Plants would start to reclaim the urban landscape.

The skyscrapers would crumble and be overtaken by vegetation.

The streets would fill with trash and debris.

The buildings would start to collapse.

The city would become a jungle.

The World Without Us is a thought-provoking book that explores the idea of what would happen to the Earth if humans were to suddenly disappear. Weisman examines how different ecosystems around the world would react to the loss of humanity, and the surprisingly quick rate at which nature would reclaim the planet.

The book is divided into several chapters, each focusing on a different region of the world. From the abandoned cities of Europe to the forests of North America, Weisman shows how the natural world would respond to the absence of humanity.

Miss Rita Cohen a tiny pale-skinned girl who looked half the age of Seymour's daughter Marie but claimed to be some six years older came to his facto1y one day. She was dressed in overalls and ugly big shoes and a bush of wiry hair framed her pretty face. Her eyes were dark and dreamy and her lips were full and moist.

"I'm Rita Cohen," she said breathlessly. "I've been watching you for weeks. You're the most interesting man in this dump."

Seymour was taken aback by her sudden appearance and by her forward manner. He was even more taken aback by her words. He had never thought of himself as an interesting man, and he certainly didn't think of himself as an interesting man in a dump like this.

"What do you want?" he asked gruffly, trying to hide his surprise.

"I want to talk to you," she said, looking at him with an intensity that made him feel uneasy. "I want to know everything about you."

Seymour shifted uncomfortably under her gaze. He didn't know what to say to her. He had never been the center of attention before, and he certainly didn't want to be now.

"I don't know much to tell," he said, trying to brush her off.

But Rita Cohen wouldn't take no for an answer. She kept talking to him, asking him questions about his life, about his work, about his family. Seymour found himself answering her, despite himself, drawn in by her curious eyes and her infectious enthusiasm

SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS How to cope with a child who shows outstanding musical ability? It's not always clear how best to develop and encourage their gift. Many parents may even fail to recognise and respond to their child's need until frustration explodes into difficult or uncooperative behaviour. The following are some ways to help parents and teachers of children with outstanding musical ability: 1. Recognise the signs: The first step is to recognise the signs of exceptional musical ability. This can include a natural interest in music, an ability to pick up musical concepts quickly, a strong desire to play or sing, and an exceptional ability to memorise music. 2. Provide opportunities: Provide opportunities for your child to develop their musical talents. This may include lessons with a professional music teacher, participation in music ensembles, or enrolling them in a specialist music school. 3. Set realistic goals: Set realistic goals for your child's musical development, both short-term and long-term. This will help them stay motivated and focused, and will also help you to assess their progress. 4. Encourage practice: Encourage your child to practice regularly, and to set aside dedicated time each day for music-making. This will help them to develop their skills and to maintain their enthusiasm for music. 5. Be supportive: Be supportive of your child's musical interests and endeavours. This means being available to listen to them, to offer encouragement, and to help them to overcome any challenges they may face. 6. Seek professional help: If your child is experiencing difficulty with their musical development, or if you are concerned about

Drop me a line! In our fast world of phones fax machines and computers the old-fashioned art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing altogether. Dorothy who? The only British woman scientist to win the Nobel prize should be a household name in her own country says Georgina Ferry but she is little known For the past four years I have been subjecting friends and acquaintances to the Dorothy Hodgkin test. It's very simple: when asked what I am working on I tell them I am writing the first biography of Dorothy Hodgkin. The response is almost always a blank look. Who is Dorothy Hodgkin? Why should anyone care? The answer is that Dorothy Hodgkin was a British biochemist who made major contributions to the understanding of insulin and vitamin D and was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1964. But despite her achievements she remains a mystery to many in her own country. According to the Royal Society which is celebrating its 350th anniversary this year Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize. Her achievements were groundbreaking and her work has had a lasting impact on our understanding of the human body and how it functions. But she is little known in her own country and her achievements have not been fully recognized or celebrated. This is a sad reflection on the state of science in Britain and the way we value and recognize the contributions of women scientists. As a society we need to do more to promote and celebrate the achievements of our scientists particularly those who have made significant contributions to our understanding of the human body and its many mysteries. Georgina Ferry is a science writer and author of the book Dorothy Hodgkin: A Life. She has been researching and writing about Dorothy Hodgkin's life and work for the past four years and has been shocked by the lack of knowledge

Under Sarah's Spell Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist whose paintings are designed to deceive the eye by creating the illusion of reality. Here she is interviewed by Joanna Watt There cannot he many artists who l10 not sign their work unless they are asked to. Sarah Janson a trompe-l'oeil artist is one. Her paintings are so realistic that you may find yourself reaching out to touch them, only to realize they are just paint on canvas. Her work is so convincing that it's easy to forget that it's not real. Joanna Watt caught up with Sarah to find out more about her unique style and what inspires her. Joanna Watt: Sarah, your paintings are incredibly realistic, how do you achieve this level of detail? Sarah Janson: Thank you! I think it's just a combination of attention to detail and a lot of practice. I've been painting trompe-l'oeil for a long time, so I've honed my skills over the years. I also try to observe the world around me as closely as possible, whether it's the way light falls on an object or the texture of a surface. JW: Your paintings often depict everyday objects, such as books, fruit, and flowers. Why do you choose to focus on these subjects? SJ: I think there's something interesting about the way we interact with everyday objects. They're things we see all the time, but they also have a certain beauty to them. I also like the idea of taking something mundane and making it special through painting. JW: Your paintings often have a sense of movement or depth, how do you create this effect? SJ: I think it'

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work. A. What makes a good leader? A leader is one who inspires an agent of change a developer who shows the way forward. Leadership is not about breeding or height - taller being better as the early theorists believed. Leadership is about attitude, behavior, and results. What makes a good leader?

A good leader is someone who can inspire others to follow them, and who can make decisions that benefit the organization as a whole. They are able to motivate their team members to reach their full potential, and they are able to build a positive and productive work culture.

A good leader is someone who is able to communicate effectively, both verbally and in writing. They are able to articulate their vision and goals, and they are able to listen to the ideas and concerns of their team members. They are able to build trust and credibility with their team, and they are able to foster a sense of collaboration and teamwork.

A good leader is someone who is able to adapt to changing circumstances, and who is able to navigate challenges and obstacles with ease. They are able to stay calm and composed under pressure, and they are able to make decisions that are in the best interests of the organization. They are able to learn from their mistakes, and they are able to grow and develop as a leader.

A good leader is someone who is able to delegate tasks and responsibilities effectively, and who is able to empower their team members to take ownership of their work. They are able to provide constructive feedback and coaching, and they are able to help their team members to develop their skills and abilities.

Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success Daniel Goleman examines the 'people skills' that are essential for a place at the top of your profession A The rules for work are changing We are being judged by a new yardstick - not just by how clever we are or by our training and expertise but also by how well we handle ourselves and each other.
Emotional intelligence (EI) is the key to success in today's fast-paced, competitive world. It is the ability to recognize and understand emotions in ourselves and others, and to use this awareness to guide our thoughts and actions. EI is not just a 'soft skill' - it is a vital component of leadership and personal success. In this article, we will explore the four main components of emotional intelligence and how they can help you achieve your goals.
Self-Awareness: The foundation of emotional intelligence is self-awareness. This is the ability to recognize and understand your own emotions and how they impact your thoughts and actions. Self-awareness is essential for making good decisions, building strong relationships, and achieving personal growth.
Self-regulation: Self-regulation is the ability to control and manage your emotions in a healthy and productive way. This involves being able to regulate your emotions, thoughts, and behaviors in response to challenging situations. Self-regulation is essential for maintaining a positive attitude, managing stress, and achieving your goals.
Motivation: Motivation is the driving force behind emotional intelligence. It is the ability to set goals and work towards them, even when faced with obstacles and challenges. Motivation is essential for achieving success and happiness in both personal and professional life

James - the initials stand for Phyllis Dorothy - exudes an air of quiet authority. It is easy to envisage her had she not become a creator of detective stories with more twists and turns than a spiral staircase as a headmistress of a girls' school. But then, as she smiles wryly, "I would have been an unspeakable bore." James, 69, is a rare bird indeed. Her 14 novels, including "Death in Holy Orders" and "The Children of Men," have won her a place in the literary firmament alongside Agatha Christie and Dorothy Sayers. Her work is characterized by complex, intricate plots, a keen eye for detail and a deep understanding of the human condition. But, unlike some of her contemporaries, she has never lost sight of the importance of style. Her prose is crisp, clear and beautifully crafted, with a precision that belies her gentle demeanor. Her detectives are not the usual bumbling fools or hard-boiled loners of the genre, but rather intelligent, thoughtful and often flawed individuals, struggling to make sense of a world that is increasingly complex and confusing. DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five leading British publishers about the effect of the reviews of a book on its commercial success. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are absolutely key for publishers - the first part of the newspaper we turn to. The Daily Telegraph
Publisher B Reviews are incredibly important. The Guardian
Publisher C Reviews are crucial, especially when it comes to fiction. The Times
Publisher D Reviews can make or break a book. The Independent
Publisher E Reviews are a major factor in the commercial success of a book. Financial Times
But do they? Is it really true that reviews sell books? We decided to test the theory. We took five books, each of which had received high praise from critics, and tracked their sales over a period of six months. The results were surprising.
Publisher A's book: Sales remained steady throughout the six months, but never really took off. Despite the glowing reviews, the book never became a bestseller.
Publisher B's book: Sales increased significantly in the first month after the reviews were published, but then tailed off. The book never reached the top of the bestseller lists.
Publisher C's book: Sales rose steadily throughout the six months, but never reached the heights predicted by the reviews. The book peaked at number 12 on the bestseller list.
Publisher D's book: Sales skyrocketed in the first month after the reviews were published, but then levelled off. The book reached number 5 on the bestseller list.

But he most regretted his denials that the industry aimed its advertising at teenagers. "We spent millions studying kids. We knew that they could name the three most advertised brands of cigarettes. We knew that almost 90 percent of the kids under eighteen who smoked preferred the top three advertised brands. We knew that kids who had been exposed to the most advertising were more likely to smoke. And we did nothing."

He looked around the room, his eyes searching for someone to blame. "We were too busy making money to care about the consequences of our actions. We were too busy trying to sell cigarettes to worry about the health of our customers. We were too greedy, too selfish, too stupid."

He paused, taking a deep breath before continuing. "But I'm not here to blame others. I'm here to tell the truth. And the truth is that I was part of the problem. I was part of the industry that preyed on the vulnerable and the innocent. And I'm sorry."

He looked at the crowd, his eyes filled with tears. "I'm sorry for the lives that were lost. I'm sorry for the suffering that was caused. And I'm sorry for my part in it. I hope that by telling the truth, I can help prevent this from happening again."

The room was silent, the only sound the rustling of papers as people took notes. It was a powerful admission, one that many in the room had been waiting to hear for years. And as the man finished speaking, there was a sense of relief, a sense that finally, someone was taking responsibility for the actions of the tobacco industry.

Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small mammal characterised by the sharp spines which cover its body. The hedgehogs are found in many different parts of the world none is native to either America or Australia. All species of hedgehog share the ability to roll into a tight ball when attacked so that their spines point outwards. This behaviour is known as hibernation and it is essential to their survival. Hedgehogs are nocturnal animals and they spend most of their time foraging for food. They eat insects and other small animals as well as fruits and berries. Hedgehogs are solitary animals and they only come together to mate. Males will fight each other for the right to mate with a female. Hedgehogs are important to their ecosystems because they help to control insect populations. They also act as pollinators and seed dispersers. Unfortunately many species of hedgehogs are threatened or endangered due to habitat loss and hunting. Conservation efforts are underway to protect these animals and their habitats. Blacksmiths THROUGHOUT the ages iron has exerted a powerful pull on the human imagination and the men who work it have often been regarded as much more than skilled craftsmen. Before the Industrial Revolution blacksmiths enjoyed the same status as doctors and astrologers because they were the sole providers of weapons armour and farming tools.
Their work was seen as a form of alchemy and their skills were passed down through generations with great secrecy and reverence.
The earliest known blacksmiths date back to the Iron Age around 1200 BC. They worked in small forges heated by bellows and used hammer and anvil to shape iron into tools and weapons.
Over time the art of blacksmithing spread throughout the world and different cultures developed their own unique styles and techniques.
In Europe during the Middle Ages blacksmiths were highly respected and often organized into guilds which protected their interests and maintained standards of quality.
In Japan the art of blacksmithing was elevated to a fine art with the development of the samurai class who prized the strength and beauty of their swords above all else.
In the Americas indigenous peoples were skilled blacksmiths who created tools and weapons from the iron they found in their environment.
Today blacksmiths continue to practice their ancient craft using modern techniques and tools while still honoring the traditions and skills of their ancestors.
Their work is a testament to the enduring power of human creativity and ingenuity and a reminder that some things in life are worth preserving and passing on.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares with his readers the mystical experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent: the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I will take them in the order of my climbing them. A. Mt. Everest, the highest peak in the world, and the first of the Seven Summits to conquer. B. Mt. Vinson, the highest peak in Antarctica, a challenging climb due to the extreme cold and lack of oxygen. C. Mt. Denali, the highest peak in North America, and the most challenging climb of my career, with icy slopes and unpredictable weather. D. Mt. Kilimanjaro, the highest peak in Africa, and the most beautiful climb of my journey, with lush forests and stunning vistas. E. Mt. Elbrus, the highest peak in Europe, a challenging climb due to the steep slopes and unpredictable weather. F. Carstensz Pyramid, the highest peak in Oceania, a challenging climb due to the dense jungle and steep slopes. G. Aconcagua, the highest peak in South America, and the last of the Seven Summits to conquer. Throughout my journey, I have learned the importance of perseverance, teamwork, and the power of the human spirit. This is my story of conquering the Seven Summits, and the lessons I have learned along the way.

Photographing People People are the most interesting of all subjects. A photograph with someone in it is almost always more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. Apart from the technical and artistic considerations the photographer has to be conscious of actions gestures and expressions. The subjects must be comfortable and relaxed in front of the camera, and the photographer must be able to capture these fleeting moments of interaction and emotion. The best photographers of people are those who can connect with their subjects and capture their essence in a single shot.

Here are some tips for photographing people:

1. Connect with your subject: Take the time to talk to your subject and get to know them. This will help you understand their personality and capture their essence in the photograph.
2. Be respectful: Remember that your subject is a person, not just a prop. Be respectful of their privacy and personal space, and never try to manipulate or coerce them into doing something they don't want to do.
3. Pay attention to lighting: Lighting is crucial for capturing the mood and atmosphere of a photograph. Use natural light or artificial light to create the desired effect.
4. Focus on the eyes: The eyes are the windows to the soul, so make sure to focus on them in your photograph. This will help to convey the subject's emotions and personality.
5. Capture candid moments: Candid moments are often the most revealing and natural-looking. Try to capture your subject in a moment of unawareness, such as when they are smiling or laughing.

The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. Christopher Middleton watched her in action. One minute into the annual inspection and things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel. Not that they know it yet. The receptionist reciting room rates over the phone to a potential guest is still blissfully unaware of the identity of the real guest she is doggedly ignoring. "I'll have a room with a view, please," says the guest, a tall, slender man with a mischievous glint in his eye. The receptionist, a plump woman with a bored expression, barely glances up from the computer screen in front of her. "Sorry, sir, but we're fully booked for the next two weeks," she informs him in a tone that suggests she'd rather be anywhere else. "Perhaps you could try the Travelodge down the road?" The guest pauses, seemingly considering this option for a moment before asking, "Do you have any rooms with a view of the sea?" The receptionist sighs and rolls her eyes. "Sir, we're in the middle of a city. Our rooms don't have views of the sea." The guest chuckles and says, "Ah, I see. Well, in that case, I'll just have to take my business elsewhere." He hangs up the phone and walks away, leaving the receptionist looking flustered and frustrated. As the annual inspection continues, it becomes clear that the Globe Hotel is in for a rough ride. The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst The study of handwriting to reveal a person‚Äôs character is gaining support If you applied for a job in some countries you would almost certainly be asked for a sample of your handwriting. And it would be the handwriting as much as anything else that would determine your suitability for the job. In the UK, for example, the Civil Service has long used handwriting analysis as part of its recruitment process. And in the US, some employers still use handwriting analysis as a way to assess job candidates. But handwriting analysis is not just limited to employment. Psychologists have long been fascinated by the relationship between handwriting and personality. In fact, the father of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud, was an early advocate of handwriting analysis. He believed that the way a person wrote revealed their unconscious thoughts and desires. And modern psychologists continue to study the connection between handwriting and personality, using it to gain insights into a person‚Äôs emotional and psychological makeup. So what can handwriting analysis reveal about a person‚Äôs character? Well, it can reveal a person‚Äôs level of self-esteem, their emotional stability, their creativity, their intelligence, their social skills, their level of anxiety, and even their sexual preference. All of these things can be inferred from the way a person writes. And the more detailed and legible the handwriting is, the more accurate the analysis is likely to be. But it‚Äôs important to remember that handwriting analysis is not an exact science. It‚Äôs a complex and multi-faceted process, and the results should always be interpreted with caution. The potential benefits to the volunteers themselves are far more significant than to the communities they are supposed to be helping. C. The potential benefits to the volunteers themselves are far more significant than to the communities they are supposed to be helping. D. Volunteer tourism can be a valuable tool for promoting cultural exchange and understanding between different countries.

A. It is hard to argue that the actual contribution to development amounts to a great deal directly.

Volunteer tourism, while intended to promote development in developing countries, often fails to deliver tangible results. This is because the short-term nature of these programs means that the work produced is often of a low quality or does not last long after the volunteers have left. Furthermore, the focus on the volunteers' personal experiences and the perceived cultural exchange between the volunteers and the local communities can detract from the actual needs of the community. Therefore, while volunteer tourism may provide some benefits to the volunteers themselves, it is hard to argue that it makes a significant contribution to development.

B. The potential benefits to the volunteers themselves are far more significant than to the communities they are supposed to be helping.

The University Museum of Classical Archaeology The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few surviving collections of casts of Greek and Roman sculpture in the world comprising over six hundred works. The first thing to remember about the collection is that nothing here is genuine. All the sculptures are accurate replicas cast from the originals mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
B. The Collection The collection covers a wide range of subjects and styles from the 5th century BCE to the 4th century CE. The collection includes sculptures from the Parthenon frieze, the Venus de Milo, and the Winged Victory of Samothrace, to name a few. The casts are remarkably detailed and faithful to the originals, making them an invaluable resource for studying the art and craftsmanship of ancient Greece and Rome.
C. The History of the Collection The collection was formed by Sir William Hamilton, a British diplomat and archaeologist, who began his collection in the early 19th century. He amassed a vast collection of Greek and Roman sculptures, many of which he excavated himself. After his death, his collection was bequeathed to the University of Oxford, where it has remained ever since. Over the years, the collection has been expanded through purchases and gifts, and it now stands as one of the most important collections of its kind in the world.
D. The Significance of the Collection The collection is significant not only for its historical value but also for its educational importance. The casts provide a tangible link to the past, allowing visitors to study the intricate details of ancient Greek and Roman sculpture up close. The collection has also been used extensively by scholars and researchers, providing a valuable resource

Are you too nice for your own good? When I had my first job as a waitress in a restaurant I soon learnt that the best way to get myself out of trouble was to smile sweetly at every possible opportunity. 'I'm so sorry' I beamed when I dropped the plate on the floor and it smashed into smithereens. 'Oh no worries, darling! It's not your fault at all!'. I was so desperate to be liked and to avoid any kind of conflict that I would have smiled if someone had told me I was wearing my trousers inside out.

But as I got older and gained more experience in the workplace, I began to realise that being too nice can actually hold you back. It can make you appear weak and unconfident, and it can also make it harder for people to take you seriously. So I started to tone down my smiling and to speak up more when I needed to.

It's not that I'm not a nice person anymore, but I've learned that being nice doesn't mean being a pushover. I still smile when I can, but I'm also more assertive and more willing to stand up for myself and my colleagues. And you know what? It's actually made me more popular in the workplace. People respect me more when I'm confident and assertive, and they appreciate my willingness to speak up when something needs to be done.

So if you're too nice for your own good, take a page out of my book and start standing up for yourself. You don't have to be mean or aggressive, but it's okay to be assertive and to set boundaries. Trust me, it will make you

Science flying in the face of gravity Journalist Tom Mumford joins students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. The pilot told his young passengers that it was built in 1964 a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker based on the Boeing 707 passenger craft. But as they climbed higher and higher, something strange started to happen. The students, all of them science enthusiasts, felt themselves becoming lighter and lighter until they were floating around the aircraft like astronauts in space. It was the first time anyone had experienced weightlessness in a flying aircraft. The KC-135 had been modified to create a zero-gravity environment for experiments and tests, and the students were part of a program called the Zero Gravity Research Flight Program. The program was designed to give students the opportunity to conduct experiments in weightlessness, and to learn about the effects of microgravity on living organisms, materials, and the human body. The students, who were all aged between 12 and 14, were divided into teams and given a range of experiments to carry out during the flight. The students were also given a special spacesuit to wear during the flight, which allowed them to move around freely in the zero-gravity environment. The flight was a huge success, and the students returned to Earth with a newfound appreciation of the wonders of weightlessness.
