The day I drew Picasso Richard Cork recalls how as an 78-year-old student he came face-to-face with one of the most revered artists of the century. Even seen at a distance eating his lunch at an open-air restaurant in Cannes harbour Picasso was instantly recognisable. I was an I8-year-old student filling in time before university by travelling round Europe and Morocco in a battered and unreliable van. One day I found myself in Cannes harbour and spotted a figure sitting at a table outside a restaurant. As I got closer I realised it was Pablo Picasso himself. I was stunned. I had always been fascinated by Picasso's work and here was the man himself eating his lunch in the sun. I hesitated for a moment before approaching him. 'Good afternoon Mr Picasso' I stammered. 'Ah good afternoon young man' he replied with a smile. 'How are you enjoying Cannes?' I explained that I was just passing through and was amazed to be in the presence of such a legendary artist. 'Ah well' Picasso said 'Cannes is a very pleasant place to spend some time. The climate is excellent and the people are friendly. I come here whenever I can'. I was in awe of the great man and struggled to think of anything else to say. 'I'm a great admirer of your work Mr Picasso' I managed to stammer. 'Ah yes' he replied with a twinkle in his eye 'I'm glad to hear that. I hope you're enjoying my paintings' I nodded eagerly and Picasso continued 'I'm glad to see that young people are still interested in art. It's important to keep the passion alive'. As I left him and continued my journey I felt incredibly luck

Hit and miss of mass marketing AS ALMOST everyone knows advertising is in the doldrums. It isn't just the recession. Advertising started to plummet early in 1989 well before the recession really began to bite. Advertising's problems are more fundamental and the decline is worldwide. The unhappy truth is that advertising has failed to keep up with the pace of economic change. The world has changed beyond recognition since advertising was invented in the early 20th century. Back then there were new technologies to be exploited - radio, television and computers - and new mass media to advertise in. But today there are new technologies - the internet and mobile phones - and new ways of communicating that advertisers are struggling to understand and harness. Advertising has become too expensive and too intrusive. People are turning off their televisions and radios and ignoring billboards. They are using ad-blocking software to avoid online ads. They are even boycotting brands that they feel are too pushy or exploitative. Advertisers are trying to find new ways to reach consumers but they are running into a brick wall of resistance. The public is angry about the intrusion of advertising into their private lives and the way it manipulates them with false promises. The advertising industry is also facing a crisis of confidence. Advertisers are questioning whether the traditional methods of advertising work any more. They are looking for new ways to reach consumers that are more subtle and more respectful of their privacy. There are new forms of advertising emerging such as viral marketing and guerrilla marketing that are more creative and more effective than traditional methods. POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER the peacocks that roam free within Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire expose their magnificent trains to the critical and often disdainful gaze of the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day: how in this competitive world where nature as Tennyson said - is red in tooth and claw could birds have evolved such an obvious extravagance? The peacocks' fans flame out in the heat, like a woman on a summer's day, and the hens - who are, after all, the true rulers of this kingdom - look on with a mixture of contempt and awe. They know that the peacocks are the true aristocrats of this place, and that their beauty is a weapon, a challenge to the rest of the world to keep up with them. And so they strut and preen, these creatures of the wild, like queens in a court of kings, and the hens, who are their subjects, must acknowledge their superiority. For in this world, as in all others, power dressing is a matter of life and death. 24

NATURAL TALENTS In the mere seven million years since we humans separated from chimpanzees we haven‚Äôt had time to develop any differences: genetically we‚Äôre still more than 98 per cent identical to chimps. On this grand evolutionary scale whatever it is that separates humans from animals is a very recent development. The idea that humans have a natural talent for anything is therefore a bit of a myth. Our talents are largely the result of cultural and social learning rather than any innate differences from other species.

For example:

* Music: we have no natural talent for music. It‚Äôs a learned skill that requires years of practice and training.
* Language: our ability to communicate with language is not a natural talent but a learned skill. Babies are born without the ability to speak and must learn language through exposure and social interaction.
* Art: we have no natural talent for art. Artists are not born with an innate ability to create beautiful works of art but rather develop their skills through practice and training.

In short we have no natural talents. What we take for granted as innate abilities are actually the result of cultural and social learning.

The idea that humans have natural talents is a myth that has been perpetuated throughout history. From ancient Greece to modern times this belief has been used to justify social inequality and to support the idea that some people are inherently more talented than others.

In reality our talents are largely the result of cultural and social learning rather than any innate differences from other species. This means that anyone can develop their talents regardless of their background or genetic makeup.

So the next time you hear someone say that they have a natural talent for something remember that

In the 1920s the Wrigley Company introduced Juicy Fruit which became the most popular brand in the world. The company‚Äôs founder William Wrigley Jr was a chewing gum enthusiast who invented the product to keep his workers at his factory in Chicago amused during their lunch breaks. Chewing gum was originally invented by the ancient Mayans and Aztecs who chewed chicle a natural latex to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. By the early 1900s chewing gum had become a popular habit in the United States and Europe and Wrigley‚Äôs Juicy Fruit was one of the most popular brands. Today chewing gum is sold in more than 100 countries around the world and is enjoyed by millions of people every day. Chewing gum has also become an important part of popular culture with references in music and film. The Wrigley Company has even launched a campaign to promote the benefits of chewing gum including improved digestion and fresher breath. Chewing gum is no longer just a simple pleasure but a global industry worth billions of dollars.

THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER A. Tamburlaine the Great Marlowe‚Äôs ten-act epic about the all-conquering warrior can seem never-ending but it emerges as one of the most thrilling nights of the year in Terry Hands‚Äô staging. He has hacked great chunks from the text and offers a production that combines the glories of Marlowe‚Äôs play with an exhilarating speed and physicality.
The story of Tamburlaine‚Äôs rise from shepherd to emperor is told in a series of frenetic, often hilarious set pieces, with the cast of 17 actors leaping, rolling and somersaulting around the stage. The production is a visual and theatrical feast, with a stunning design by Tim Hatley that incorporates projections, lighting and a giant rotating globe.
The play is a classic tale of ambition and power, but it‚Äôs also a riotous satire of the excesses of the Elizabethan age. Marlowe‚Äôs language is rich and poetic, and the cast deliver their lines with a fierce passion that makes the play feel alive and dangerous.
There are some memorable performances, notably from Joseph Mykell as Tamburlaine and his arch-enemy, the Grand Turk (played by Paul Chahidi). The chemistry between the two actors is electric, and their scenes crackle with tension and energy.
The production is not without its flaws ‚Äì the pacing can be uneven, and some of the scenes feel overly long or repetitive. But overall, this is a thrilling and unforgettable evening at the theatre, a testament to the power of Marlowe‚Äôs writing and the skill of Hands‚Äô direction.

Nick James on The Abyss. The Abyss is a gripping, claustrophobic thriller that combines the best elements of James Cameron's earlier sci-fi films, such as Aliens and The Terminator, with a Cold War-era political subtext.
The film follows a group of oil rig workers who are recruited by the navy to rescue a nuclear submarine that has become stranded miles beneath the surface of the ocean. As they descend into the depths of the sea, the team faces numerous challenges, including a malfunctioning life support system, a hostile alien environment, and a sinister government agent who is hiding a dangerous secret.
Despite some of the more implausible plot developments, The Abyss is a visually stunning and emotionally intense film that explores themes of patriotism, sacrifice, and the human condition.
The cast, led by Ed Harris and Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, deliver strong performances, and the special effects are groundbreaking for their time. Overall, The Abyss is a must-see for fans of sci-fi and action movies, and it remains one of the most thought-provoking and entertaining films of the 1980s.

The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition. It‚Äôs a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others. But transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Unless that is it is newspapers‚Äô ‚Äòtransition‚Äô to the online world an uncertain and highly uncomfortable process ‚Äì because frankly it may not be a process at all. For the past week or so, I have been mulling over the fate of the newspaper business. And I have come to the conclusion that the end of print may take some time.

For a start, there are still plenty of people who read newspapers every day. Sure, the circulations are down, but there are still millions of people who rely on newspapers for their news and information. And even if the circulations continue to fall, there will still be a market for newspapers ‚Äì especially for those who prefer to read their news on paper rather than on a screen.

But beyond that, there are other factors at play here. Newspapers have a long and storied history, and they have played a vital role in shaping the way we think about the world around us. They have provided a platform for journalists to report on important issues, and they have given voice to marginalized communities. And even if the print edition of a newspaper is no longer the dominant form of news delivery, that doesn‚Äôt mean that the role of newspapers in society is over.

In fact, the transition to online news may actually give newspapers a new lease on life. With the internet, newspapers can reach a global audience and provide a platform for journalists to report on stories that might not have been possible in the past. And with the rise of social media, newspapers can now reach a new generation of readers who may not

The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from perfectly crafted furniture Joanna Watt meets him Charles Hurst gives the impression of being a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop tucked under a railway arch in East London and am greeted with a quick handshake and the words: 'Well fire away then!' Whether this brusqueness is real or a front hiding a shy streak is not immediately apparent. But as we talk, it becomes clear that Hurst is a man of many facets. He is a skilled craftsman who has spent decades honing his trade, but he is also a designer, an entrepreneur, a husband and father. He is passionate about his work, and his enthusiasm is infectious. Hurst's day job is running his own furniture-making business, which he started in the early 1990s. He has a small team of skilled craftsmen who work alongside him, and they produce a range of beautiful pieces, from chairs and tables to beds and cupboards. His designs are characterised by clean lines, simple shapes and a careful attention to detail. 'I'm not a fan of clutter,' he says. 'I like things to be simple and elegant. I think that's what makes good design.' Hurst's work is highly sought after by discerning clients, and he has won several awards for his craftsmanship. But he is also a man of the people. Ancient Chinese medicine in the West? Acupuncture is two thousand years old. It comes from the traditional Chinese system of medicine that includes herbalism massage diet manipulation and exercise. It is used to treat many different conditions but acupuncture‚Äôs role in treating pain has received most attention by doctors in the West.
Acupuncture involves the use of fine needles that are inserted into specific points on the body. It is based on the belief that there are channels or pathways in the body through which the life energy or Qi flows. When these channels become blocked or imbalanced the body‚Äôs health can suffer. Acupuncture is thought to restore balance to the body by stimulating these channels and allowing the flow of Qi to resume.
Acupuncture is a relatively safe procedure when performed by a licensed practitioner. However there are some risks associated with it including infection and injury from the needles. Additionally some people may experience side effects such as bleeding or bruising at the site where the needles are inserted. It is important to discuss any concerns or potential risks with a licensed acupuncturist before undergoing treatment.
Acupuncture is used to treat a wide range of conditions including chronic pain migraines and headaches arthritis and fibromyalgia. It is also used to help manage addiction and to improve overall health and well being. While the evidence supporting acupuncture‚Äôs effectiveness is mixed some studies suggest that it may be helpful in managing certain conditions. It is important to talk to a healthcare provider before undergoing acupuncture to determine if it is right for you.
In conclusion acupuncture is an ancient Chinese medical practice

Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives asleep. It seems certain therefore that sleep has a vital function. However what that function might be is still in debate. Scientists are far from being in agreement about precisely why so much of our precious time is given over to sleep. Here are three theories: 1. Restoration Theory: According to this theory, sleep is a time of restoration for our bodies. During sleep, our bodies are able to repair and regenerate tissues, build bone and muscle, and strengthen our immune systems. 2. Energy Conservation Theory: This theory suggests that sleep is a way for our bodies to conserve energy. When we are awake, our bodies use a significant amount of energy to maintain basic functions such as breathing, digestion, and circulation. Sleep allows us to conserve this energy and use it more efficiently during the day. 3. Brain Processing and Consolidation Theory: This theory proposes that sleep plays an important role in the processing and consolidation of memories and learning. During sleep, our brains are able to sort through and file away memories, and to solidify new learning and knowledge. In addition, sleep may also help us to better process and understand emotions, and to regulate our emotional responses. In conclusion, while we still have much to learn about the function of sleep, these three theories offer some insight into the many ways in which sleep is essential for our overall health and well-being. By understanding the role that sleep plays in our lives, we can better appreciate the importance of getting enough sleep each night. References: 1. National Sleep Foundation. (2015). S

THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING I thought everyone would be pleased but one of my colleagues was absolutely furious. ‚ÄòWhat do you mean?‚Äô she raged. ‚ÄòIf it was that easy why didn‚Äôt you stop years ago?‚Äô I suppose my inability to explain how one afternoon I had been a packet-a-day life-long smoker and four hours later I was not was faintly irritating. But I was smiling, feeling proud and relieved, and I didn‚Äôt really care.

That was 1994. It‚Äôs now 2018 and I‚Äôm still a non-smoker. It‚Äôs been 24 years and counting. I‚Äôm not saying it‚Äôs been easy. I‚Äôve had the occasional urge, the odd craving, the temptation to light up. But I‚Äôve always been able to resist, thanks to a combination of willpower, support from friends and family, and the knowledge that I‚Äôve already come so far.

It‚Äôs amazing how quickly you can get used to something. Smoking was a part of my daily routine, something I did without thinking. Waking up in the morning, having a cigarette while I got dressed, taking a break at work to smoke, smoking after dinner, before bed. It was like breathing. And then, suddenly, it wasn‚Äôt.

Of course, I miss it sometimes. I miss the ritual of lighting up, the taste of the smoke, the way it made me feel. But I don‚Äôt miss the smell, the stains on my fingers and clothes, the constant coughing, the worry about my health. And I certainly don‚Äôt miss the way it affected my relationships with others.

Looking back though my handwritten school essays I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over.
Johnson was a pioneer of the handwritten essay and in his view the process of writing by hand was essential to the quality of the writing. He believed that writing by hand required more effort and concentration than writing on a keyboard, and that this effort and concentration resulted in better writing.
He also believed that writing by hand helped to cultivate a more intimate and personal connection between the writer and the words they were writing.
In contrast, writing on a keyboard allows for greater speed and ease of composition, but it can also lead to a more impersonal and generic style of writing.
Johnson‚Äôs views on the importance of handwriting are particularly relevant in today‚Äôs digital age, where many people are increasingly reliant on technology for their writing. With the rise of email, text messaging, and social media, the handwritten letter has become a rare and precious thing.

Writing is a fundamentally human activity, and it involves a complex interplay between the mind, the hand, and the page.

I had the street to myself, but the buildings seemed to loom over me, their facades as blank as the backs of strangers. The avenue's architecture was a mix of old and new, with some buildings bearing the weight of age and others gleaming with a fresh coat of paint. I passed a few shops and restaurants, but they seemed to be holding their breath, waiting for something to happen. As I walked, I felt the city's pulse beating in time with my steps, a steady rhythm that matched the drip of the rain on my umbrella. I had no destination in mind, just the need to move, to put one foot in front of the other and keep going. As I walked, I tried to shake off the feeling of being lost, of being a small and insignificant speck in a city of millions. Einstein Stop anyone in the street and ask them to name a scientist and the chances are they‚Äôll think of Albert Einstein. His face is used to advertise products with intellectual connotations from computers to encyclopaedias. He is the go-to figure for anyone wanting to illustrate the power of human intelligence. But, as David Bodanis points out in his book, "Einstein: A Life in Science", this is a very partial view of the man and his achievements.

Einstein was not just a scientist, but a passionate advocate for social justice. He was a strong supporter of the civil rights movement in the United States and was involved in various other political causes. He was also a gifted writer and musician, with a love of poetry and the arts.

Einstein's most famous equation, E=mc¬≤, is often seen as the ultimate symbol of his brilliance, but it was only one part of his work. His theories on relativity, quantum mechanics and the nature of space and time are some of the most important scientific discoveries of the 20th century.

Despite his many accomplishments, Einstein was a humble man who never sought to draw attention to himself. He was known for his kindness and generosity, and his love of simple pleasures like sailing and playing the violin.

Fashion Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon entirely dependent upon nineteenth- and twentieth-century capitalism for its development. Most historians of fashion are at pains to point out though that fashion at least in the sense of style and design has a very long history. They often take the rise of the market and mercantile trade in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries as their starting point. From this perspective, fashion is a relatively recent development, emerging as a result of the growth of capitalism and the rise of a consumer culture. This view is certainly correct in the sense that the modern fashion industry is a product of the capitalist system and the rise of mass production and mass marketing. However, it is also true that the desire for stylish clothing and adornment has been present in human societies for thousands of years. The history of fashion is thus a complex and multifaceted one, encompassing both the economic and social factors that have shaped the industry and the aesthetic and cultural values that have influenced the development of style.

Metals It may have been a wish for self-adornment that aroused the interest of Stone Age people in metals. Sitting by the side of a river waiting for a fish to come within a spears throw or just idling away a moment one of our early ancestors might have happened upon a shiny yellow pebble and plucked it off the river bed. The pebble may have been a piece of pyrite or some other mineral that shone like gold in the sunlight. Perhaps the early man was fascinated by the pebble and decided to test its properties. He might have discovered that the pebble could be shaped and molded into various forms, that it could be hammered into thin sheets, and that it could be alloyed with other minerals to create different colors and properties. He may have realized that the pebble had a certain strength and durability and that it could be used to create tools and weapons. The discovery of metals would have been a turning point in the history of human civilization. It would have marked the beginning of a new era of innovation and technological advancement. With the discovery of metals, people would have been able to create more sophisticated tools and weapons, and to build more durable shelters and structures. They would have been able to trade and exchange goods more easily, leading to the development of complex societies and economies. The discovery of metals would have also led to the development of new technologies, such as smelting and alloying, which would have allowed people to create a wide range of metal objects, from jewelry and decorative items to agricultural implements and machines. THE WELL I had read somewhere that from a sufficiently deep hole one could see the stars if the day were clear. I had persuaded you to help me with my scheme; you watched eyes wide fist to mouth as I winched up the well bucket steadied it on the wall and then climbed in. The rope went taut and I was swung upwards my feet kicking at the air. The hole was deep and I could hear the sound of my own breathing echoing back at me. I could see the stars as promised but they were pale and distant. The sky was a deep blue and the earth was a distant memory. I felt small and insignificant in the vastness of the universe. The rope went slack and I was lowered back down to the ground. You were there to catch me and help me out of the well. You asked me what I had seen and I told you the stars. You nodded and smiled and said it was a good thing I had seen them. We walked back to the house in silence. I knew that I would never forget the feeling of being suspended in the void with the stars above me. And I knew that I would never forget the feeling of being caught and held by someone I loved.

Ralph unlocked the door to his let and as he entered the dark motionless hall experienced that momentary qualm of ownership which even after three years still lightly besieged him sometimes when he returned alone at the end of the day.

As he hung up his hat in the rack near the door and put his coat away in the closet he felt the hall's familiar embrace. It was a small house, but it was his own, and he had made it so with his own hands. He had painted the walls a warm cream color, and had covered the windowsills with greenery, and had made the old furniture his own with cushions and covers in bright colors.

Ralph had bought the house three years ago, when he had first moved to the city. He had been a young man then, eager to make his way in the world, and the house had seemed the perfect place to start. It was small and cozy, and it had a garden at the back that he could tend. He had worked hard to make the house his own, and it had become his sanctuary, a place where he could retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city and be himself.

As he stood in the hall, Ralph felt a sense of contentment wash over him. He was home, and everything was as it should be. He took off his shoes and put on his slippers, and padded barefoot into the living room. The room was dark, but he could make out the shapes of the furniture, and he could feel the warmth of the fire that was still burning in the grate

Heritage The true meaning and significance of heritage is that it gives people and communities a genuine sense of connection with the past. Obviously we feel connected to our personal heritage usually we know who and what our grandparents were and we will have heard stories about how they lived. But heritage is more than just our family history. It is also the customs, traditions, values and beliefs that have been passed down from generation to generation within a community or society.
It is the collective memories and experiences of a group of people which shape their identity and sense of belonging.
Heritage is important for several reasons:
It helps us understand our past and how it has shaped our present.
It provides a sense of continuity and stability in a rapidly changing world.
It fosters a sense of identity and belonging, which is essential for individual and community well-being.
It helps us to appreciate and respect cultural diversity and the differences that make us unique.
It provides a shared sense of history and culture, which can help to bring people together and promote social cohesion.
It is a source of pride and inspiration, and can help to motivate people to work towards a better future.
Heritage is not just about preserving old buildings and historical artifacts, it is about preserving the memories, traditions and values of our ancestors, which are the foundation of our identity and sense of belonging.
It is important to preserve our heritage for future generations, so they can learn about and appreciate their cultural and historical roots.
Heritage is a living and dynamic concept, it is not just a collection of old buildings and artifacts, but a living part of our communities

I was wrong to question his age and I now have the opportunity to make a full apology. Fearon was outstanding as Othello, bringing a freshness and intensity to the role that I have not seen before. His performance was so compelling that I found myself forgetting that I was watching a well-known actor on stage. He was able to convey the vulnerability and insecurity that underpins Othello‚Äôs jealousy and rage, and his delivery of the famous ‚ÄúO, beware, my lord, of jealousy!‚Äù speech was one of the most powerful moments in the play. His Othello was not a one-dimensional villain but a fully rounded character with all the complexities of Shakespeare‚Äôs creation. The supporting cast was also excellent, particularly Hugh Quarshie as Iago and Indira Varma as Desdemona. Quarshie‚Äôs Iago was a masterpiece of acting, a perfectly calibrated performance that made the character‚Äôs duplicity and malevolence all the more chilling. Varma was a sweet and gentle Desdemona, whose tragic fate was all the more heartbreaking because of her innocence and purity. Observing Lions In the popular imagination lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case their next meal.

But the reality is far more complex. Lion social dynamics are not always as harmonious as they seem. In fact while lions do hunt together they often engage in fierce territorial battles and occasionally even turn on each other to protect their prides.

This complex social structure is one of the reasons why lions are so fascinating to study. Researchers can learn a great deal about their behavior by observing how they interact with each other and how they manage to cooperate despite their natural inclination towards aggression.

For example a study published in the journal Science found that lions will sometimes go without food for days rather than risk upsetting the balance of their pride. This is particularly interesting given that lions are not typically known for their selfless nature.

In conclusion while the image of lions hunting together may be a compelling one it is important to remember that their social dynamics are far more complex and nuanced than they may seem at first glance. By studying these dynamics researchers can gain valuable insights into the behavior of these magnificent creatures and help to protect them for future generations.

Garbage in garbage out Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems environmentally sound and economically sensible. It may not be. Some rituals of modern domestic living vary little throughout the developed world. One such is the municipal refuse collection: at regular intervals rubbish bags or the contents of rubbish bins disappear into the bowels of a special lorry and are carried away to the local tip. In some parts of the world the rubbish is compacted and sent to landfill sites; in others it is burned. But however it is disposed of, the idea that each household should be responsible for its own waste is gaining ground. In some countries, such as Denmark and Sweden, households are already charged for every bag of rubbish they produce. The principle is simple: the more rubbish a family produces, the more it should pay. The Danish government has set up a system of "refuse taxes", under which each household is charged a small sum for each bag of rubbish it produces. The tax is based on the weight of the rubbish, and the amount paid increases as the weight of the rubbish rises. The Swedish government has introduced a similar system, known as "producer responsibility". Here, too, the amount paid increases with the weight of the rubbish. The idea behind these schemes is that by making households pay for the disposal of their rubbish, they will be more inclined to reduce the amount they produce in the first place. The argument goes that if households had to pay for every bag of rubbish they produced, they would be more likely to recycle, compost and reduce their overall consumption of disposable products. And the more a household reduces its waste, the less it will have to pay in refuse taxes or producer responsibility charges. The environmental benefits

0ral History The growing trend for historians to rely on oral evidence is not without its problems. It is naive to suppose that someone‚Äôs testimony represents a pure distillation of past experience for in an interview each party is affected by the other. The interviewer may introduce their own biases, and the interviewee may be influenced by their relationship with the interviewer.
The oral history interview is a conversation between two people, and as such, it is shaped by the dynamics of that relationship. The interviewer‚Äôs tone of voice, body language, and choice of words can all affect the way the interviewee responds. Even the most skilled interviewer can inadvertently introduce their own biases into the interview.
Moreover, the process of oral history is not always reliable. Memories can fade, and people can misremember or embellish events. It is also possible for interviewees to intentionally mislead or deceive the interviewer. In some cases, interviewees may be motivated by a desire to please the interviewer or to promote their own interests rather than to provide an accurate account of the past.
In addition, the oral history method can be limited by the fact that it relies on the memory of a single informant. This can lead to a lack of diversity in the perspectives and experiences that are represented in the historical record. It can also result in a narrow or biased view of the past, as the interviewer may be more likely to select informants who share their own perspectives or who are likely to provide the most sensational or provocative information.

'You don't take sugar do you? shouted his secretary not so much asking a question as stating a fact - as well she might because she had been making Lancelot cups of coffee for many months. Her excuse for forgetting such things was that he wasn‚Äôt normally supposed to be there.

Lancelot smiled wryly to himself and shook his head. He did take sugar, but he wasn't about to tell her that. It was one of the small pleasures of being a vampire - being able to enjoy the taste of coffee without having to worry about the consequences. He had been drinking it for years, ever since he had been turned, and he had long since learned to appreciate the subtle differences in flavor that came with each new batch of coffee beans.

'Of course not,' he said, trying to sound as nonchalant as possible. 'I don't take sugar. I'm not really much of a coffee drinker, to be honest.'

His secretary looked at him skeptically, but he could tell she didn't entirely believe him. She knew him too well. Still, he was grateful for her discretion. It was one of the things he liked about working with her - she was always so careful not to pry.

As he drank his coffee, Lancelot couldn't help but feel a sense of nostalgia wash over him. He had been drinking this very same coffee for years now, ever since he had first been turned. Vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth describe how one day the dominant male in the group of vervet monkeys they were studying noticed a strange male hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger‚Äôs intentions were quite obvious: he was sizing up the group in order to join it.
The dominant male was not pleased, and he let the stranger know it by chasing him off. But the stranger didn‚Äôt give up easily. He kept coming back, day after day, trying to win his way into the group.
The dominant male, however, was having none of it. He began to act aggressively towards the stranger, chasing him and even attacking him. The other members of the group, who had been watching all this from a distance, began to take sides. Some of them sided with the dominant male, while others sympathized with the stranger.
As the days passed, the tension between the two males grew. The dominant male became increasingly aggressive, and the stranger became more and more desperate. Finally, in a dramatic confrontation, the dominant male chased the stranger all the way to the edge of the group‚Äôs territory. There, he confronted the stranger and attacked him viciously, driving him out of the group forever.
Cheney and Seyfarth note that this kind of aggressive behavior is common among vervet monkeys, and that it serves several purposes. For one thing, it helps to maintain the stability of the group. By driving out potential rivals, the dominant male can prevent any challenges to his authority, and keep the group in line.

AESTHETICS By one of the ironic perversities that often attend the course of affairs the existence of the works of art upon which formation of aesthetic theory depends has become an obstruction to theory about them. For one reason: these works are products that exist externally and physically. They have a history of production, distribution, and reception. They are objects that can be seen, handled, and possessed. They are not merely mental constructs or imaginary entities. They are things that can be appreciated and enjoyed in themselves, and their value or significance can be measured by their material qualities and the way they appeal to our senses.

But for another reason: the works of art that are most important for aesthetic theory are often the very ones that are least accessible to direct experience. They are works of art that are difficult to understand, or that have a complex or ambiguous meaning. They are works that require a knowledge of art history, literary theory, or philosophical analysis in order to be fully appreciated. They are works that are not simply beautiful or enjoyable in themselves, but that also have a complex or ambiguous significance that requires interpretation and analysis.

In both cases, the existence of the works of art themselves becomes an obstruction to aesthetic theory. For on the one hand, the materiality of these works makes it difficult to understand their significance or value in terms of purely mental constructs or imaginary entities. And on the other hand, the complexity or ambiguity of these works makes it difficult to understand their significance or value in terms of direct experience or immediate sensory appreciation.

The result is that aesthetic theory has tended to be caught up in a kind of circularity or

Sand Much as I admire sands miraculous ability to be transformed into useful objects like glass and concrete I am not a great fan of it in its natural state. To me it is primarily a hostile barrier that stands between a seaside car park and the water itself. It blows in your face gets in your sandwiches and swallows vital objects like car keys and coins.
I have been known to take a few ill advised steps into the surf only to find myself up to my ankles in the stuff. It is like walking on a never ending stretch of wet spaghetti. It makes a mess of your toes and your clothes and leaves you feeling like you need a bath.
But despite all this I know that sand is a vital part of the beach ecosystem. It is the foundation of the sand dunes that protect the coastline from erosion and flooding. It is the breeding ground for countless species of birds and insects and it is the home of countless tiny creatures that live in the sand.
So I guess I will just have to learn to appreciate sand in all its messy and unpredictable glory. It is a reminder that even in the most beautiful places there can be challenges and difficulties to overcome. And who knows maybe one day I will even learn to surf.
Labels: beach, sand, surfing

Art on TV Why is it that television so consistently fails when it comes to programmes about the visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be natural subjects for the camera which has the ability to show a whole work of art then move in close to examine the details.
In the past, art programmes on television have been the subject of much criticism. They have been accused of being dull, pretentious, and inaccessible to a general audience. So why is it that television so consistently fails when it comes to programmes about the visual arts? Painting and sculpture should be natural subjects for the camera, which has the ability to show a whole work of art and then move in close to examine the details.
One reason for this failure may be that television is not well-suited to the subject matter. Painting and sculpture are complex and subtle, and they cannot be easily reduced to sound bites or visual gimmicks. They require a more thoughtful and considered approach, which may not be the strength of television as a medium.
Another reason may be that television is often more interested in personalities than in art. Artists are often portrayed as eccentric or enigmatic figures, rather than as serious artists with a body of work to be appreciated. This can make the programmes feel more like celebrity profiles than serious art appreciation.
Finally, there may be a lack of understanding and knowledge about the visual arts within the television industry itself. Many television producers and executives may not have a deep understanding of the subject matter, and may be more interested in sensational or controversial content than in providing a thoughtful and informative programme about art

The Actor‚Äôs Craft Derision and contempt are sprayed at actors from time to time. Some actors feel that they are being reduced to mere commodities, rather than respected artists. This makes them defensive and hostile towards the media and the public. The following are some of the reasons why actors are often ridiculed and looked down upon:
1. Over-glorification: The media often creates an image of actors as glamorous, wealthy, and successful. This creates a false impression of the profession and sets unrealistic expectations for the public. When actors fail to meet these expectations, they are ridiculed and criticized.
2. Lack of understanding: Many people do not understand the complexity of the actor‚Äôs craft. They assume that acting is easy and that anyone can do it. This lack of understanding leads to disrespect and contempt for actors.
3. Over-emphasis on personal lives: The media often focuses on the personal lives of actors rather than their work. This creates an impression that actors are more interesting for their personal lives than their professional achievements.
4. Misconceptions about the actor‚Äôs role: Some people believe that actors are merely decorative elements in a film or play, rather than artists who bring characters to life. This misconception leads to disrespect and contempt for actors.
5. Unrealistic expectations: The public often has unrealistic expectations of actors, expecting them to be perfect in every role

In his book How Work Works, Theodore Zeldin, a psychotherapist and social critic, explores the deep-seated reasons for this discontent and offers a vision of a new kind of working life that would be more fulfilling and beneficial for all. He argues that the current model of work is based on the idea that people are interchangeable parts, and that work is something to be endured until retirement. Zeldin suggests that work should be seen as an integral part of life, something that brings us joy, fulfillment, and a sense of purpose. He argues that we need to move away from the traditional model of work and towards a more flexible, creative, and fulfilling approach. He also suggests that we need to rethink the way we measure success and recognize the value of all kinds of work, not just the traditional professions. By challenging our assumptions about work and the way we organize our society, Zeldin offers a vision of a more equitable and sustainable future for all.

Paul Simon Rock and roll in the 1950s was primarily a youth cult but its lasting importance lay in the seismic impact it had on the middle class and the middle-aged. It also paved the way for the next generation of rock idols who listened to it awestruck and aware that this strange unsettling sound would somehow irrevocably be linked with their destinies. The 1950s were a time of great social change and upheaval, and rock and roll was a reflection of that. The music was a way for young people to express their frustration with the status quo and to challenge the conventions of their elders. Elvis Presley, Chuck Berry, Little Richard, and Jerry Lee Lewis were the first generation of rock stars, and their music was a call to rebellion and freedom. They sang about cars, girls, and dancing, but they also sang about the struggles of growing up and the desire for independence. The music was raw, energetic, and unapologetic, and it spoke to a generation of young people who were looking for a way to express their own identity and to challenge the rules and expectations of their parents. In the 1960s, rock and roll continued to evolve, and it became a powerful force for social change. Bob Dylan and The Beatles were among the most influential musicians of this era, and their music reflected the growing awareness of social and political issues. Dylan's songs spoke of the civil rights movement and the Vietnam War, while The Beatles explored themes of love, drugs, and spirituality. POETRY RECITALS At any given time in history the literary scene will seem confused to those who are living through it and it is the selectivity of posterity that makes the pattern and orders of eminence appear clearly defined to the retrospective view.
- F.R. Leavis, "The Great Tradition"
The literary scene is always in a state of flux, with new voices and styles emerging all the time. But as F.R. Leavis notes in his essay "The Great Tradition," it is only with the benefit of hindsight that we can truly understand the patterns and orders of eminence that emerged in the literary landscape.
As a poet, I have always been fascinated by the way that poetry can capture the essence of a particular moment in time. Whether it is the political and social upheavals of the 1960s, the personal and emotional struggles of the 1980s, or the technological and cultural shifts of the 21st century, poetry has the power to distill these moments into something that is both timeless and uniquely of its time.
One of the ways that I approach this task is through the practice of poetry recital. By reading my own and others' poems aloud, I am able to bring the words to life in a way that is different from simply reading them on the page. The sound and rhythm of the words, the inflection and intonation of the voice, all combine to create a unique and powerful experience for the listener.

CRYING Charles Darwin thought that the human tendency to cry had no obvious evolving purpose. He was almost certainly wrong. More recently scientists have pointed to its social significance with psychiatrist John Bowlby highlighting the role of crying in developing the attachment between mother and child. Many believe that tears at least during childhood are mainly an expression of helplessness. But as adults we cry for a range of reasons including grief sadness and even simple pleasure. As humans we have evolved to be highly social creatures and crying is a powerful way to communicate our emotions to others. It may well have evolved to serve social functions. For example crying can elicit empathy and support from others and may even have evolved to act as a form of communication in its own right. Whether crying evolved to be a byproduct of other evolutionary adaptations or as a direct adaptation itself the fact that it is such an integral and universal part of human experience suggests that it must have some important function.

The passage suggests that Charles Darwin may have been incorrect in his assumption that the human tendency to cry has no obvious evolving purpose. In fact, scientists have identified several potential reasons why humans might cry, including:

1. Social significance: Crying is believed to play a role in developing the attachment between mother and child, and as adults, we cry to communicate our emotions to others.
2. Helplessness: Tears may be an expression of helplessness, particularly during childhood.
3. Grief and sadness: Crying is a common response to loss and sadness.
4. Simple pleasure: Crying can also be a response to joy or simple pleasure.

The Lure of the Kitchen When I was at university I decided I wanted to be a chef. Among my contemporaries this was an unusual choice. Cooking was not one of the plum jobs that most of us wanted. It is on the face of it an unattractive profession. Chefs lead notoriously harsh lives: the work is long pressured menial - and badly paid. The hours are unsocial and the pay is low. Even the most successful chefs are often subject to the whims of their employers and are frequently bullied and humiliated by the kitchen staff. In my case I think I was attracted to the kitchen because of the promise of creativity and self-expression. Cooking is a form of artistic expression and I enjoyed the idea of creating something beautiful and satisfying from raw materials. I also enjoyed the social side of the kitchen. It is a place where people come together to share food and drink and to enjoy each other's company. I was also drawn to the kitchen because of the sense of tradition and history that it represents. Cooking is a skill that has been passed down through generations and it has a rich cultural heritage. I was excited by the prospect of being part of this tradition and of contributing to it in my own way. In the end I did not become a chef. I discovered that I was not cut out for the long hours and the physical demands of the job. I also found that I was not as creative as I had thought and that I was not as good at cooking as I wanted to be. I still enjoy cooking and I still appreciate the artistry and tradition of the kitchen. But I have come to realize that the lure of the kitchen is not just about the food. It is also about the sense of community and tradition that it represents. It

How to Write Poetry Telling people how to write poetry is a bit like frolicking through a minefield: spontaneity is the order of the day but one false step and a dozen certainties will blow up in your face.



But since you asked so nicely, I will share a few of my own poetic techniques, and the way I approach the craft.

First, I find it helpful to read a lot of poetry. Not just the works of other poets, but also poetry itself. I mean, I read a lot of other things too, but poetry is the thing that feeds my soul.

When I come across a line or a phrase that strikes me as particularly beautiful or effective, I'll dog-ear the page or make a note in the margin. I keep a file of these lines and phrases, and sometimes I'll go back through them and try to incorporate them into my own work.

Another technique I use is to write about the things that are most important to me. This could be a person, a place, a memory, or an emotion. I find that when I write about what's truly on my mind and in my heart, the words flow more easily and the poem feels more authentic.

I also try to use language in unexpected ways. I love to play with metaphor and simile, to find new ways to describe things that are familiar to us all. This can help to create a sense of wonder or surprise, and can also make the poem more memorable.

Finally, I think it's important to be willing to take risks in your writing

In theory anyone could publish a manifesto or broadcast a music channel on the Internet. In practice however a certain amount of technical know-how was required at least in the early years. In the 1990s many people were able to bypass this requirement by using simple web-based tools such as GeoCities and Angelfire. However as the Internet became more complex and sophisticated these platforms became less accessible to the average user. Love them fear them worship them human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. But what does that say about us? Paul Evans reports There's a bump bump bump coming from the greenhouse as a little brown shuttlecock bounces against the glass. It turns out to be a wren: an ominous bird a bird of portent augury and divination. In the Western world, at least, birds have long been associated with the supernatural, the divine, and the unknown. They are the messengers of the gods, the harbingers of doom, the interpreters of dreams. In ancient Egypt, the ibis was a symbol of Thoth, the god of wisdom and magic. In Greek mythology, the owl was a companion of Athena, the goddess of wisdom and war. In medieval Europe, the raven was a harbinger of doom and death, while the dove was a symbol of peace and redemption. Even in modern times, birds continue to fascinate us with their beauty, their grace, and their otherworldly nature. They are the stuff of poetry and song, the subject of countless paintings and photographs. And yet, as much as we love and fear them, we also worship them. We worship their beauty, their grace, and their otherworldly nature. We worship the way they soar through the sky, their wings outstretched, their hearts full of joy and freedom. We worship the way they sing, their voices rising and falling like the tides of the sea. And we worship the way they connect us to the natural world, to the rhythms and rhymes of the earth and sky. In short, we worship the way birds make us feel alive, connected, and a part of something greater than ourselves. So

Every Picture Tells a Story Adapting novels for film almost always involves a process of reduction condensation and deletion. This can be very frustrating for the writer but also illuminating. Working on a script I was struck by how much of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene in the novel I could dispense with while still getting across the same point. The images on the page told me what was important. The words in the text were superfluous. The same with character description. The way a character looked was less important than how they behaved. The way they walked and talked was more revealing than their physical features. The same with backstory. The novel might spend pages on the characters history but in the adaptation I could condense it down to a few key details that were relevant to the scene at hand. The process of adaptation taught me to be more concise in my writing and to trust that the images I created would tell the story.
The process of adaptation also taught me to be more attentive to the language I used. Because I was working with a limited amount of time and space I had to be precise in my language and to cut out anything that was not essential to the scene. This was a liberating experience because it forced me to think about the words I was using and to choose them more carefully. It also made me more conscious of the way I structured my sentences and paragraphs. The result was that my writing became more efficient and more effective.
In addition to these technical lessons the process of adaptation also taught me something about the nature of storytelling itself. I came to realize that the best stories are those that are economical and efficient. They are not bogged down by unnecessary details or excessive exposition. The Heat is On We‚Äôve all heard of global warming but just how much warmer will the earth get and how will it affect our lives? Almost everyone has some idea of what global warming is all about but no one is quite sure about its consequences. A warmer climate is likely to mean changes to the weather in all parts of the world.
The earth‚Äôs average temperature has already risen by about 0.8 degrees Celsius since the late 1800s, and this warming trend is expected to continue unless greenhouse gas emissions are significantly reduced. According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the earth‚Äôs average temperature could rise by another 2 to 5 degrees Celsius by the end of the century if greenhouse gas emissions continue to rise at their current rate. This could lead to more frequent and severe heat waves, droughts, and storms, as well as rising sea levels and more acidic oceans.
The effects of global warming will not be felt equally by all. The poor and vulnerable populations, such as those living in small island developing states, least developed countries, and arctic communities, are likely to be disproportionately affected by climate change. Rising sea levels, for example, could lead to the displacement of people living in low-lying areas, while more frequent and intense storms could damage homes, infrastructure, and agriculture, leading to food and water shortages.
In addition to the direct physical effects of global warming, there are also potential indirect effects on human health, economic stability, and social and political stability. Maps The purpose of a map is to express graphically the relations of points and features on the earth‚Äôs surface to each other. These are determined by distance and direction. The map is a two-dimensional representation of a three-dimensional surface.
Maps are essential tools for navigation, urban planning, and many other fields. They provide a visual representation of an area‚Äôs topography, land use, and other features. Maps can be created using a variety of techniques, including:
1. Cartography: The art and science of creating maps. Cartographers use a variety of techniques to create maps, including:

a. Projection: The process of transforming the curved surface of the earth into a flat surface.

b. Scale: The relationship between the distance on the map and the distance on the ground.

c. Symbolization: The use of symbols and colors to represent different features on the map.

d. Generalization: The process of simplifying the map by reducing the amount of detail.

2. Remote sensing: The process of creating maps from data collected by sensors or satellites. Remote sensing can be used to create maps of:

a. Land use: The way an area is used, such as agriculture, urban development, or conservation.

b. Land cover: The types of vegetation, water, and other features that cover an area.

c. Topography: The shape and elevation of the earth‚Äôs surface.

HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American executives are adopting the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model of good management. Eluned Price reports. Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a rough idea of what he did. He led three British expeditions to the Antarctic between 1907 and 1922, and his 1914-17 Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition, which aimed to cross the continent from coast to coast, was one of the most remarkable feats of endurance and leadership in history. But the reason why Shackleton has been rediscovered in recent years as a model of good management is less well known. In 2007, Tim Jarvis, a former Australian soldier and adventurer, led an expedition to retrace Shackleton's journey across the Antarctic, using the same ship and equipment that Shackleton had. The expedition was a success, but it also highlighted the qualities that made Shackleton such an effective leader. Jarvis says, "Shackleton was a people person. He was able to inspire and motivate his team, even in the most dire circumstances." This is a quality that many modern executives are looking for in their own leaders. In today's fast-paced and competitive business world, leaders need to be able to inspire and motivate their teams to achieve their goals. MUSIC AND THEATRE Up until quite recently I would have said that opera is first and foremost theatre. Not any more. After a brief spell working at u national opera house I learned that opera is in fact only secondly theatre. The music comes first. That‚Äôs as it should be of course. Opera is a form of musical drama, and the music is the heart and soul of the art form. But the theatre is crucial too. It provides the setting, the characters, the dramatic structure, the visual and aural framework in which the music can shine. Without the theatre, the music would be abstract and unmoored. Without the music, the theatre would be dull and uninteresting. The two art forms are inextricably linked, and the best opera productions are those that find the perfect balance between the two. So what‚Äôs the key to making opera work on stage? Well, for starters, the singers need to be both vocally and dramatically excellent. They need to be able to convey the emotions and intentions of their characters through their voice alone, and they need to be able to act as well as sing. It‚Äôs a tall order, but it‚Äôs one that many opera companies are able to fill. The directors and designers also play a crucial role in bringing the opera to life. They need to be able to interpret the composer‚Äôs intentions and translate them into a visual and aural experience that complements and enhances the music. It‚Äôs a delicate process, but one that can result in some truly magical moments. And then there‚Äôs the orchestra. Without the orchestra, the opera would be nothing more than a series of vocal performances.

In this passage, the author is discussing the term "broadcasting" and its origins. The author argues that the term originally referred to the act of sowing seeds broadly by hand, which is an agricultural metaphor that symbolizes the idea of planned growth and the production of a rich harvest. The author suggests that this metaphor is not only agricultural but also modernist, as it implies a sense of optimism and control over the growth process. The author goes on to suggest that this metaphor has been applied to the field of communication and broadcasting, where it has taken on a new meaning, referring to the distribution of information to a wide audience through various media channels.

The author is using the term "social shaping" to describe the way in which language and culture shape our understanding of technology and its applications. By examining the origins of the term "broadcasting," the author is able to reveal the cultural and historical context in which the term was developed, and to show how it has evolved over time.

The author is also using a rhetorical device called synecdoche, where a part of something is used to represent the whole.
